tossups.question: Baker clamps are circuits that can reduce the storage time in one type of these devices, while the creation of a low-impedance path may cause latchup in another type of these devices. High current densities may cause the Kirk effect in these devices, and a variation in width of the bases of these devices causes the Early effect. The Gummel-Poon model for these devices can reduce to the simple Ebers-Moll model. Gold foil was put over the vertex of a triangle in the earliest example of these devices called (*) point-contact. These devices may operate in active, cutoff, or saturation modes, and one type of them can be classified as PNP or NPN types. The base, collector, and emitter comprise the bipolar junction type of these devices, which have been replaced with the MOSFET type. The number of these devices on a computer chip doubles about every 2 years by Moore’s Law. For 10 points, name these devices that can be used as amplifiers or switches.

Heitor Villa Lobos’ Choros No. 2 is scored for flute and this instrument. The third movement of Olivier Messiaen’s Quartet for the End of Time is an extremely slow solo for this instrument depicting an “abyss.” Near the end of his career, Brahms composed two sonatas for this instrument dedicated to Richard Muhlfeld, and two concertos for it were written by (*) Carl Maria von Weber. An A major piece for this instrument and string quartet and a concerto for it in the same key were written by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart for Anton Stadler. This instrument plays a glissando at the start of Rhapsody in Blue. For 10 points, name this single-reed wind instrument pitched in A or B-flat.

This country’s national borders were effectively reduced by an order from French general Ferdinand Vix. In this country, Prime Minister Sandor Wekerle was forced to resign after the Aster Revolution. This country’s first prime minister after the fall of communism was Jozsef Antall, and the “salami tactic” was used to eliminate fascists in this nation by Matyas Rakosi. It’s not the Soviet Union, but the White (*) Terror followed the Red Terror in this country after Bela Kun was overthrown by Miklos Horthy. This country followed a policy of “goulash communism” under Janos Kadar, who was put in power after a 1956 independence movement under Imre Nagy (NAHJ) was crushed by Soviet Tanks. For 10 points, name this country home to the Magyars whose union with Austria dissolved after World War I.

This book’s epigraph is from The Graphographer and contains the quote “I write. I write that I am writing.” In one section of this novel, a psychologist tells a man to hit kids while he drives. After being accused of rape, the Jehovah’s Witness Gumercindo Tello threatens to castrate himself. In this book, Pascual, the protagonist, and the second title character are all hired by the Genaros. Near the end of this book, the protagonist and the first title character try to find a mayor who is willing to officiate the marriage of a minor to a woman in her thirties. The even chapters of this book are all (*) plays whose characters eventually end up dying because of the insanity of the dramatist, Pedro Camacho, who works at Radio Panamerica. For 10 points, name this semi-autobiographical novel where Mario marries his divorced relative, by Mario Vargas Llosa.
tossups.answer: Aunt Julia and the Scriptwriter or La tia Julia y el escribidor <Mathew>
tossups.answer_formatted: Aunt Julia and the Scriptwriter or La tia Julia y el escribidor <Mathew>
acceptable: Aunt Julia and the Scriptwriter or La tia Julia y el escribidor <Mathew>
Aunt Julia and the Scriptwriter or La tia Julia y el escribidor <Mathew>

tossups.question: One thought experiment from this school of thought imagines a child drowning and argues that it is worth muddying your clothes to rescue them and was originally published as “The Drowning Child and the Expanding Circle.” In Methods of Ethics, one thinker from this school compared this school of thought to institutional morality and another thinker expounded an anarchic version of this school in his Enquiry Concerning Political Justice. Those thinkers are Henry Sidgwick and (*) William Godwin, respectively. This school advocates against the “tyranny of the majority” and was founded by the authors of The Principles of Morals and Legislation and On Liberty. For ten points, name this philosophical school founded by Jeremy Bentham and John Stuart Mill, whose ethics seeks the greatest good for the greatest number of people.

A young couple roleplay being a prostitute and customer in this author’s short story The Hitchhiking Game. He described his love of Diderot’s Jacques the Fatalist and Sterne’s Tristram Shandy in his seven-essay collection The Art of the Novel. This author created a character whose tombstone reads “He wanted the kingdom of God on Earth” and whose bowler-hat-wearing lover hates kitsch; he also wrote about the consequences of a postcard sent to Marketa by (*) Ludvik Jahn in The Joke. His best-known work describes the life of the photographer Tereza and her surgeon husband Tomas during the Prague Spring and its aftermath. For 10 points, name this Czech-born French writer of The Unbearable Lightness of Being.

A method of measuring quality in sausages uses 3-methylhistidine to identify this protein. It’s not amyloid, but the brains of patients with Alzheimer’s disease often contain more aggregates of this protein called Hirano bodies. Latrunculins prevent this 42-kilodalton protein from polymerizing, while another poison found in the death cap mushroom prevents this protein’s depolymerization. That poison is also used to stain this protein and is called (*) phalloidin. The beta isoform of this protein can be used as a loading control in Western blotting. Treadmilling occurs when molecules are added to polymers of this protein at the same rate that they are removed; those polymers of these proteins are called thin filaments. For 10 points, name this protein that is is also bound to myosin during muscle contraction.

This civilization was cited as an early example of a “world-economy” by Fernand Braudel in his book Capitalism and Material Life. Matinu, a member of the 12 Kings alliance at the Battle of Qarqar, was the king of this people’s city-state of Arwad. The tomb of this civilization’s King Ahiram was where its alphabet, a predecessor of Greek which consisted of 22 (*) consonants, was discovered. Gods worshipped by these people include Melqart and Astarte. These people who founded Beirut became famous for a dye used to color Roman imperial clothing, Tyrian purple. According to legend, the most famous city founded by this civilization was once ruled by Dido. For 10 points, name these seafaring people of the eastern Mediterranean who founded Carthage.

The Jain Digambaras only carry a peacock feather and a container for this substance. In the Quran, Hagar runs between Safa and Marwa in search of this substance for her son Ishmael. The Hindu goddess Ganga produces a pure form of this substance, and devotees mix ashes with this substance. This substance covers the body in Amrit Sanchar and misogi, (*) a Sikh initiation ceremony and Shinto ritual purification, respectively. While under the reign of Nebuchadnezzar, Daniel refuses to have anything but vegetables and this drink. Jesus turns this drink into wine at the wedding of Cana, and later walks on this substance in the middle of a storm. For 10 points, name this substance in which people are dipped for baptism.

A character in this work is said to possess the slowly weakening soul of an ancient Greek mathematician. A plan in this work involves blowing air onto raw onions to test sailors for the plague. The title character complains about being condemned for poisoning a clergyman’s cook, while another character is ordered to perform everything backwards after throwing her handkerchief at a disguised man selling medicine on stage. In this play, a disinherited son foils the title character’s plan to rape (*) Celia as Corvino, Corbaccio, and Voltore attempt to win the title character’s inheritance. The title character fakes his own death with his servant Mosca at his bedside. For 10 points, identify this play about a Venetian nobleman by Ben Jonson.

During this man’s exile in Canada, he met North-West Mounted Police chief James Walsh. After winning an auction, Minnesota businessman Alvaren Allen took this man on a 15-city tour beginning at Allen’s St. Paul hotel. Caroline Weldon served as this leader’s personal secretary but left shortly before he was killed by Lieutenant Henry Bullhead and Red Tomahawk. At Fort (*) Buford, this man famously had his son Crow Foot give up his rifle. This man died after being arrested on fears he would spread the Ghost Dance movement. Before his most famous battle, this man had a vision of many soldiers falling like grasshoppers into his people’s camp. For 10 points, name this Hunkpapa Lakota leader who allied with the Cheyenne to win the Battle of Little Bighorn.

In one scene referencing the events of this film, a photograph is used to identify the mysterious title character. One of the other characters in that photograph, played by Eugene Brave Rock, says that he has nothing left to fight for due to the acts of white men and sends smoke rings to signal the main character. After a battle in this film, Charlie is heard (*) singing, which is very rare. After leaving Themyscira, Steve Trevor goes back to London to deliver Doctor Poison’s book in this film. For 10 points, name this film created by DC Comics that chronicles the journey to find and kill Ares, led by the title character, an Amazon demigoddess who possesses bulletproof gauntlets and a lasso of truth.

One algorithm for doing this task generates a sequence using iterated polynomials and investigates the cyclic part of that sequence. Another algorithm for doing this process tries to find smooth perfect squares. Besides Pollard’s rho algorithm and Dixon’s method, another algorithm for doing this process includes a subroutine to find the period of an exponential function using (*) Hadamard gates and a quantum Fourier transform. That algorithm, with complexity class BQP, would theoretically break RSA encryption and is named after Shor. Fermat’s method for doing this process writes odd numbers as a difference of two squares. The most basic algorithm for doing this process can be stopped at the square root of n and basically divides numbers through trial-and-error. For 10 points, name this process that decomposes an integer into a product and ends when there are no composite numbers left.

This country was home to an architect who designed a namesake vase for the Savoy restaurant in its capital. Another architect from this country designed the Vyborg railway station and Buffalo’s Kleinhans Music Hall. For the Gullichsen family, an architect from this country designed the Villa Mairea; that architect’s projects in the US include MIT’s Baker House. Artek still sells chairs created by one architect from this country for TB patients at the (*) Paimio Sanatorium. An architect from this country designed the Noyes dormitory at Vassar College as well as the Kresge Auditorium and MIT Chapel. This country is home to Alvar Aalto, as well as the designer of the Gateway Arch, Eero Saarinen. For 10 points, name this country with capital Helsinki.

In what is now this country, rulers known as Omukamas from the Chwezi dynasty controlled the kingdom of Bunyoro-Kitara. This nation’s current president has been opposed in four elections by Kizza Besigye. After a power struggle, this country’s first leader removed the ceremonial president Edward Mutesa II. It’s not Rhodesia, but this country’s “Bush War” resulted in the overthrow of Tito (*) Okello by its current president. The most notorious ruler of this country was overthrown in a war with a neighboring country ruled by Julius Nyerere. This site of the Entebbe Raid has been ruled since 1996 by a man who defeated Joseph Kony’s Lord’s Resistance Army, Yoweri Museveni. This country’s first leader, Milton Obote, was overthrown by a man who expelled all Asians from his country. For 10 points, name this country once led by Idi Amin.

Shortly after this man’s death, a set of erotic sketches by him known simply as “Twenty-five Drawings” was published. This man depicted the tree of life in one of three mosaics he created for the Palais Stoclet. Another work by him contrasts a young woman and child on the right with an old woman at the left and is titled The Three Ages of Women. This artist of Water Serpents and the Judith series also painted two portraits of the socialite (*) Adele Bloch-Bauer. The artist of the Beethoven Frieze, his most famous work shows two lovers embracing and includes his trademark gold leaf. For 10 points, name this member of the Vienna Secession who painted The Kiss.

As a result of this decision, a 14-year-old boy was shot in the face with a rubber bullet during a protest. Eliot Engel, the top Democrat on the House Foreign Affairs Committee, claimed this step helped “correct a decades-long indignity.” Hungary blocked an attempt by the EU to formally criticize this decision. Shortly after this decision, a similar step was taken by Jimmy Morales, the president of (*) Guatemala. Honduras was the only other major country to vote against a resolution condemning this event. Following this event, Nikki Haley called the UN “one of the world’s foremost centers of hostility toward” the country that it affected, and it prompted Hamas to call for a new intifada. For 10 points, name this step taken by the Trump administration to move a certain country’s embassy from Tel Aviv.
tossups.answer: Recognition of Jerusalem as the capital of Israel (accept clear-knowledge equivalents; accept moving the US embassy to Jerusalem) <Sivakumar>
tossups.answer_formatted: Recognition of Jerusalem as the capital of Israel <Sivakumar>
acceptable: Recognition of Jerusalem as the capital of Israel <Sivakumar>
Recognition of Jerusalem as the capital of Israel <Sivakumar>
tossups.metadata: accept clear-knowledge equivalents; accept moving the US embassy to Jerusalem

tossups.question: This novel originated as the verse play Proud Flesh, in which the main character was named Talos after a “brutal, blank-eyed ‘iron groom’” from the Fairie Queene. That character begins the novel by stopping at a soda fountain and talking to “Old Leather-Face” about his jailed son; he is later contrasted as “the man of fact” against a “man of idea.” After picking up a hitchhiker, this novel’s narrator formulates a theory of the (*) “Great Twitch” and studies his ancestor Cass Mastern. He digs up blackmail evidence against Judge Irwin, causing Irwin to commit suicide before he realizes Irwin was his father. In this novel, Anne Stanton’s affair with “the Boss” is revealed, causing Adam to shoot him. For 10 points, name this novel narrated by Jack Burden about the Huey-Long-inspired politician Willie Stark, by Robert Penn Warren.

One of these figures was born from a reed shoot that grew between heaven and earth. Another of these figures was killed when she coughed up game, and her death caused the separation of day and night. When subjected to a test of strength, the hand of another of these figures first turned into an icicle and then a sword. That transformation is the beginning of the contest that inspired a famous regional fighting style. As a result of one of these figures trapping his wife behind a (*) boulder, the human cycle of life and death was created. One of these figures was born from the left eye of her father and hid in the Heavenly Cave to escape her brother, Susano-o; she was eventually lured out using a brightly colored festival. For 10 points, name these figures, which include Amaterasu, Izanami, and Izanagi, the primary deities of Shinto mythology.
tossups.answer: kami [prompt on descriptions like “Shinto spirits” before “Shinto” is read] <Orlov>
tossups.answer_formatted: kami <Orlov> [prompt on descriptions like “Shinto spirits” before “Shinto” is read]

tossups.question: The fulminate of this element is often used as a friction-sensitive explosive in percussion caps. Minamata disease is caused by a compound containing this element bound to a methyl group, and this element’s chloride is used as a catalyst to produce vinyl chloride from acetylene. Potassium, iodine, and this element are found in a compound that turns yellow when exposed to ammonia; that reagent is named after (*) Nessler. This element is found at the bottom of the apparatus used in the Castner-Kellner process, and a dimethyl compound containing this element killed Karen Wetterhahn when it seeped through her glove. The alternative name for thiols indicates their affinity for this element, and the red pigment cinnabar contains this element bound to sulfur. For 10 points, name this element, which can be found in thermometers, with symbol Hg.

bonuses.leadin: This expedition ended following the successful siege of Gaeta. For 10 points each:
answers: Expedition of the Thousand (or Spedizione dei Mille)
parts: Name this Sicilian expedition which overthrew the Bourbon king Francis II.
The Expedition of the Thousand was led by this Italian patriot. He also fought for the Colorado faction in the Uruguayan Civil War.
This man ceded Garibaldi’s birthplace of Nice to France, prompting Garibaldi to call him “a low intriguer.” He later became the first prime minister of a unified Italy.

bonuses.leadin: This man composed an 1866 funeral march after the death of his friend Rikard Nordraak. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Norwegian composer of Lyric Pieces and the Peer Gynt Suite.

In Grieg’s only work of this type, the main instrument enters with a falling minor second-major third motif after a timpani roll. It is often compared with a similar work in the same key by Robert Schumann.
Grieg also composed this set of pieces for piano which ends with an allegro con brio “rigaudon” movement. This collection was written for the 200th birthday of a Norwegian-born playwright.

bonuses.leadin: During his first presidential campaign, this man mocked US Ambassador Spruille Braden’s “Blue Book” by publishing his own “Blue and White Book.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this president who served three terms from 1946 to 1974. Several of his supporters were killed by snipers in the Ezeiza massacre.
After the 1955 Revolución Libertadora, Perón escaped north to this country on a gunboat provided by its dictator Alfredo Stroessner.
Perón’s wife Isabel was succeeded by this dictator, who instituted the National Reorganization Process. The majority of the Dirty War took place during his rule.

bonuses.leadin: A watery diarrhea stool is a characteristic of this disease. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this disease, which was studied by John Snow during an epidemic in London.

Heterozygous carriers of mutation Delta F508, which can cause this disorder, are more resistant to cholera. People with this disorder may have difficulty absorbing and maintaining reserves of Vitamin K.

In young patients with cystic fibrosis, this bacterium is often the most common in the respiratory tract. This Gram-positive bacterium secretes the TSST-1 superantigen, which can cause toxic shock syndrome.

bonuses.leadin: Now that you’ve all had lunch, answer some questions about some odd international delicacies. For 10 points each:
parts: The stinkiest of all fruits, durian, is notoriously banned on this city’s MRT. Also a country, this city amusingly gained independence from Malaysia against its own will in 1965.
Hákarl is a traditional fermented shark dish, which tastes of ammonia, from this country. This country also contains the most powerful waterfall in Europe, the Dettifoss.
Casu marzu is a maggot-infested cheese from this Italian region. This region’s highest peak is Punta La Marmora on the Gennargentu Massif, and its artificial Lake Omedeo is Italy’s largest reservoir.

bonuses.leadin: This writer read his poem The Gift Outright at John F. Kennedy’s inauguration. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this American writer of “Stopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening” and “The Road Not Taken.”
This Frost poem describes the death of Silas on the farm of his former employers William and Mary.
“The Death of the Hired Man” is part of this poetry collection named for a city, whose other poems include “After Apple-Picking” and “Mending Wall.”

bonuses.leadin: In Shinto weddings, the couple drinks from three cups of the rice kind of this drink. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this drink. In Genesis, Noah lay naked in his tent after he drunk this liquid.
Samson found this other food in a lion’s carcass. John the Baptist ate only locusts and this food while he lived in the desert.
On Rosh Hashanah, Jews eat this food dipped in honey in hopes for a sweet new year.

bonuses.leadin: This man depicted the exploration of Africa in Five Weeks in a Balloon. For 10 points each:
answers: From the Earth to the Moon <Sivakumar>
parts: Name this French author who described Phileas Fogg in Around the World in Eighty Days.
In Verne’s Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea, the French marine biologist Pierre Aronnax, his servant Conseil, and this harpooner are held captive on the Nautilus by Captain Nemo.
This other Verne novel describes the Baltimore Gun Club’s attempts to launch three people to the second titular object.
acceptable: From the Earth to the Moon <Sivakumar>
From the Earth to the Moon <Sivakumar>

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer some questions about pre-Socratic philosophers’ ideas about the nature of the universe.
parts: This founder of atomism claimed that all atoms must move in straight lines in an argument for determinism. He also believed that the gods lived in a world devoid of atoms.
This philosopher used the idea of arche, or originating principle, to conclude that everything must be made of the same substance. He decided that water was that substance.
This philosopher feuded with Heraclitus about the nature of the universe, arguing that everything is made of one universal substance that is unchanging.

bonuses.leadin: Arias in this work include “Guardate, pazzo son!” and “In quelle trine morbide.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this opera about the title character’s love for the Chevalier des Grieux.
This composer wrote the music for Manon Lescaut but is better known for Turandot and Madama Butterfly.
Like Puccini, this composer used the story of Manon Lescaut for his opera Manon. A “Meditation” is often excerpted from his opera about a courtesan, Thais.

bonuses.leadin: This man is best known for an event at Baltimore and Potomac Railroad Station. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this man, who stated “I am a Stalwart of the Stalwarts” after his most famous action.
Guiteau assassinated this US president, who defeated Winfield Scott Hancock in the election of 1880.
Guiteau had previously been a member of this Perfectionist religious community. After leaving, he sued its founder John Humphrey Noyes.

bonuses.leadin: The strength of this phenomenon is multiplied by the two-thirds power of volume in the Eötvös rule. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this property of liquids caused by cohesive forces. This property can be lowered by surfactants.
The De Noüy method, which is used to calculate the surface tension in a liquid, uses a ring made of this metal. Adam’s catalyst contains this element along with oxygen and hydrate.

A long chain of platinum atoms are bound to either ammonia groups or chlorides in this person's “green salt.” This man also discovered a famous physical effect important in sports such as soccer and table tennis involving bending caused by rotation of the ball.

bonuses.leadin: This man described Captain McWhirr’s experiences aboard the SS Nan-Shan in his novella Typhoon. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Polish-born author, who more famously described Marlow’s obsession with the ivory trader Kurtz in Heart of Darkness.
This Conrad novel describes the titular Italian expatriate, who saves Captain Gould’s silver from the revolutionary General Montero in Costaguana.
Conrad’s novel Lord Jim describes the title character’s experience on this steamer, which sinks while transporting religious pilgrims to a Red Sea port.

bonuses.leadin: This novel is alternately narrated by a gold coin, Satan, and the corpse of a murdered man. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this novel about Ottoman miniaturists, in which Elegant Effendi is murdered and Black falls in love with Shekure.
My Name is Red and Snow are written in this language. Other books in this language include “Memed, My Hawk” by Yasar Kemal.
This Turkish author of The Museum of Innocence wrote My Name is Red.

bonuses.leadin: Peter Barlow formulated an incorrect version of this law by setting current proportional to the inverse square root of length. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this law, which in its simplest form states that voltage equals current times resistance.
This other law, which states that the magnetomotive force equals the magnetic flux times the magnetic reluctance, is the magnetic analogue of Ohm’s law.

This man generalized Ohm's Law to the equation “J equals sigma times E.” This man was also the first to use the term “blackbody radiation,” and he is also the namesake of a diffraction formula and integral theorem.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about Dutch Renaissance artists. For 10 points each:
parts: This painter depicted several young and old people playing instruments around a dinner table in The Merry Family. His other family scenes include The Drawing Lesson and The Dancing Couple.
The artist Frans Hals is best known for this painting, which shows a soldier in full costume with an enigmatic smile.
This man painted a self-portrait in a red turban and the Madonna of Chancellor Rolin, but is better known for The Arnolfini Wedding.

bonuses.leadin: Italo Calvino published a collection of 200 of these works from Italy. For 10 points each:
answers: folk tales (accept folklore, prompt on fairy tales or mythology)
parts: Name these works described by the Aarne-Thompson index. These works are usually derived from oral traditions and often take the form of fables or proverbs.
This term for an inauthentic folk tale described as if it was traditional was originally coined by Richard M. Dorson. He used the example of Pecos Bill to illustrate this term.
Although some stories about this figure are genuinely traditional, the majority of them originated from the Red River Logging Company, including the stories about his blue ox, Babe.
metadata: accept folklore, prompt on fairy tales or mythology

bonuses.leadin: This state was founded in 882 by Prince Oleg. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this state ruled by the Rurikid dynasty, governed from its namesake Ukrainian city.
The Rus’ were thought to be an offshoot of these Scandinavian seafarers, whose leaders included Cnut the Great and Leif Eriksson.
This prince of Kiev and Novgorod expanded Kievan Rus’ to its greatest extent. He codified the laws of Kiev, forming the basis for the later Russkaya Pravda law code.

bonuses.leadin: Name some mythological figures who owned farms. For 10 points each:
parts: Helios has a sacred group of these animals that Odysseus’s men weren’t supposed to touch. Ymir also has a pet one of these milk-producing creatures.
As part of Hercules’ 10th labor, he had to steal the cattle of this monster, who had three heads and three pairs of legs.
During the Cattle Raid of Cooley, this Ulster hero single handedly fights of the men of Connaught, as he is the only warrior that isn’t disabled by a curse.

bonuses.leadin: Light and dark bands on these objects are called ogives. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these large, slow-moving masses of ice that may leave behind moraines.
When glaciers retreat, these types of shallow lakes may be formed. Walden Pond is a famous example of these types of lakes.
This term describes any large glacial outburst flood from a subglacial or proglacial lake. This term is derived from the name of the largest glacier in Iceland.
